<div class="markdown"><h1>Disk Imaging</h1>
<p><strong>Astro 497, Week 12, Friday</strong></p>
<p>Acknowledgement to Prof. Ian Czekala&#39;s <a href="https://iancze.github.io/courses/astro542/lectures/">Astro 542</a> and <a href="https://iancze.github.io/courses/astro589/lectures/01-introduction/">Astro 589</a>.</p>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Types of Disks</h2>
<ul>
<li><p>Protostellar</p>
<ul>
<li><p>Circumstellar</p>
</li>
<li><p>Circumbinary</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p>Protoplanetary</p>
<ul>
<li><p>Gas/Primary </p>
</li>
<li><p>Dusk/Debris</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Protostellar cores collapsing to form stars</h2>
<p>When the core becomes gravitationally unstable, it will begin to collapse. </p>
<p>The free-fall timescale is </p>
<p class="tex">$$\tau &#61; \sqrt&#123;\frac&#123;3 \pi&#125;&#123;32 G \rho&#125;&#125;$$</p>
<p>Optically thick, so can&#39;t see into what&#39;s happening at this phase.</p>
</div>

<pre class='language-julia'><code class='language-julia'>let
 	G = 6.6743e-8 # cm^3 g^-1 s
    ρ_sol  = 1.41
    sec_in_day = 24*60*60
    days_in_year = 365.2425
    τ = sqrt(3π/(32*G*ρ_sol)) / sec_in_day
    r = 10.0.^(-2:0.25:2)
    r_sol = 0.005
    scalefontsizes()
    scalefontsizes(1.5)
    plot(r, τ.*(r./r_sol).^3 ./days_in_year, 
        linewidth=4,
        xscale=:log10, yscale=:log10, legend=:none)
    xlabel!("r (AU)")
    ylabel!("τ (Years)")
end</code></pre>
<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,">


<div class="markdown"><h2>Protostar classes</h2>
<p>Protostellar systems &#40;protostars and their disks&#41; are conventionally divided into four different classes based on the overall shape of their infrared spectrum, characterized by their spectral index</p>
<p class="tex">$$\alpha \equiv \frac&#123;d \log&#40;\lambda F_\lambda&#41;&#125;&#123;d \log \lambda&#125;.$$</p>
<p>i.e.,</p>
<p class="tex">$$\nu F_\nu \propto \nu^&#123;-\alpha&#125;.$$</p>
<p>Observationally, this is usually calculated using observations done at 2.2 microns &#40;K-band&#41; and 10 microns &#40;N-band&#41;, which are observable from the ground.</p>
<img controls='' src='https://iancze.github.io/courses/astro542/lectures/30-star-formation-observations/vanthoff_thesis.png' type='image/png' width='80%'></img>
<p>Schematic overview of the different stages of low-mass star formation &#40;left&#41; and the observational classification based on the spectral energy distribution &#40;right&#41;.  Credit: <a href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019PhDT........31V/abstract">Merel van’t Hoff, Ph.D. thesis</a>.</p>
<ul>
<li><p>Planets can be recognized by their sculpting of Stage III protoplanetary disks.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><div class="admonition is-tip">
  <header class="admonition-header">
    Question:
  </header>
  <div class="admonition-body">
    <p>How does the type of star affect the characteristics of the protoplanetary disk?</p>
  </div>

</div>

<ul>
<li><p>More massive stars have more massive protoplanetary disks &#40;initially&#41;.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Eventually, the disk disperses</p>
</li>
<li><p>Age of star/disk is most important parameter.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><div class="admonition is-tip">
  <header class="admonition-header">
    Question:
  </header>
  <div class="admonition-body">
    <p>Are certain disk classes more common than others? </p>
  </div>

</div>

<ul>
<li><p>Every star passes through each stage</p>
</li>
<li><p>Observed occurence rate tells us about how long a star spends in each stage.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Entire process </p>
</li>
<li><p>Until large mid-IR surveys, Stage 0 were rare because most emission in mid-IR</p>
</li>
<li><p>Stage I disks are rare because they collapse quickly</p>
</li>
<li><p>Stage II disks are relatively common.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Stage III stage can last millions of years, but they are are rarely detected because they are hard to detect disks when they have low mass mass</p>
</li>
<li><p>Transitional disks &#40;with both gas and dust&#41; are particularly valuable, but also rare because gas is rapidly dispersing as dust emerges.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

<pre class='language-julia'><code class='language-julia'>question_box(md"Is there a limit to how long a protoplanetary disc can last, and what might happen to it after its lifetime has come to an end?")</code></pre>
<div class="markdown"><div class="admonition is-tip">
  <header class="admonition-header">
    Question:
  </header>
  <div class="admonition-body">
    <p>Is there a limit to how long a protoplanetary disc can last, and what might happen to it after its lifetime has come to an end?</p>
  </div>

</div>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><img controls='' src='https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/17/Mamajek09_diskfraction.jpg' type='image/jpeg' width='80%'></img>
<p>–- Credit: <a href="https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.3215910">Mamajek 2009</a> Lincense: <a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/deed.en">CC BY-SA 3.0</a></p>
</div>

<pre class='language-julia'><code class='language-julia'>question_box(md"When measuring a disk mass, are we able to tell how wide the disk is from out perspective or are we assuming the volume to be a chosen value?")</code></pre>
<div class="markdown"><div class="admonition is-tip">
  <header class="admonition-header">
    Question:
  </header>
  <div class="admonition-body">
    <p>When measuring a disk mass, are we able to tell how wide the disk is from out perspective or are we assuming the volume to be a chosen value?</p>
  </div>

</div>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Infrared Excesses</h2>
<ul>
<li><p>Most systems are so far away that don&#39;t resolve disks</p>
</li>
<li><p>Measuring excess emission in IR &#40;relative to model for star&#41; provides evidence for disks and estimates of their mass.</p>
</li>
<li><p>The closest stars with infrared excesses make great targets for disk imaging.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><h1>Disk observations as a function of wavelength</h1>
<h2>Optical &#40;and some NIR&#41; observations</h2>
<ul>
<li><p>Optically thick: </p>
<ul>
<li><p>Disk blocks starlight/other parts of disk</p>
</li>
<li><p>Requires detailed modeling</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p>Optically thin: </p>
<ul>
<li><p>See light scattered by grains</p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><p>Atmosphere makes detecting faint disks close to star difficult</p>
</li>
<li><p>Hubble Space Telescope best source of good disk images in optical</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h2>IR observations</h2>
<ul>
<li><p>See thermal emission &#40;plus molecular transitions&#41;</p>
</li>
<li><p>Often measure IR excess, but too far away to resolve disk.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Lower spatial resolution for given size observatory due to diffraction limit</p>
</li>
<li><p>Ground-based observatories have larger aperture than HST</p>
</li>
<li><p>Adaptive optics starts to become effective in near-IR</p>
</li>
<li><p>Great images of nearby diks from Ground-based observatories with sophisticated AO systems</p>
</li>
<li><p>Disks are particularly challenging due to high contrast ratio.  </p>
</li>
</ul>
<h2>Sub-mm &amp; Radio observations</h2>
<ul>
<li><p>See thermal emission from dust</p>
</li>
<li><p>See molecular transitions &#40;especially rotation&#41;</p>
</li>
<li><p>Hyperfine splitting &#40;e.g., 21 cm&#41;</p>
</li>
<li><p>Single disk observations have low resolution due to long wavelength</p>
</li>
<li><p>Interferometry becomes practical in sub-mm and allows for even better resolution</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>ALMA</h2>
<img controls='' src='https://iancze.github.io/courses/astro589/lectures/01-introduction/alma.jpg' type='image/jpeg' width='80%'></img>
<p>The Atacama Large &#40;Sub&#41;millimeter Array, an interferometric array of 66 antennas operating at sub-millimeter wavelengths. The largest antennas in the array are only 12m in diameter, yet through interferometry, the array is able to obtain far higher spatial resolution than the largest single-dish antennas. Credit: NRAO/ESO/NAOJ/JAO</p>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><img controls='' src='https://iancze.github.io/courses/astro589/lectures/01-introduction/HLTau_ALMA.jpg' type='image/jpeg' width='80%'></img>
<p>The protoplanetary disk around HL Tau, imaged using the Atacama Large Millimeter Array. Credit: <a href="https://public.nrao.edu/gallery/hl-tau-birth-of-planets-revealed-in-astonishing-detail-2/">ALMA&#40;ESO/NAOJ/NRAO&#41;; C. Brogan, B. Saxton &#40;NRAO/AUI/NSF&#41;</a></p>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><img controls='' src='https://public.nrao.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/nrao17cb20b.jpg' type='image/jpeg' height='80%'></img>
<p>–- Credit: <a href="https://public.nrao.edu/news/2017-alma-ring-fomalhaut/">ALMA &#40;ESO/NAOJ/NRAO&#41;; M. MacGregor</a></p>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Key Questions about a Disk:</h2>
<ul>
<li><p>Optically thin or thick?</p>
</li>
<li><p>How old is disk?</p>
</li>
<li><p>What process is depleting disk?</p>
</li>
<li><p>Is disk being replenished?</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Key Questions about an observation?</p>
<ul>
<li><p>What wavelength?</p>
</li>
<li><p>What size particles are we seeing?</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><h1>Reading Questions</h1>
</div>

<pre class='language-julia'><code class='language-julia'>question_box(md"How is the mass outflow of a protoplanetary disk measured?")</code></pre>
<div class="markdown"><div class="admonition is-tip">
  <header class="admonition-header">
    Question:
  </header>
  <div class="admonition-body">
    <p>How is the mass outflow of a protoplanetary disk measured?</p>
  </div>

</div>
</div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Measuring Mass from Optically Thin Disk</h2>
<ul>
<li><p>Emission proportional to surface area of scatterers</p>
</li>
<li><p>Estimate equilibrium temperature based on host star temperature &amp; distance</p>
</li>
<li><p>Surface area to mass ratio depense on size distribution</p>
</li>
<li><p>Model size distribution as collisional cascade</p>
</li>
<li><p>Infer mass of scatterers via mass absorption coefficient &#40;<span class="tex">$\kappa$</span>&#41;</p>
</li>
<li><p>Omits mass in gas &#40;&amp; much smaller grains&#41;</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

</div>

    using PlutoUI, PlutoTeachingTools
    using Plots
end</code></pre>
